comment_text.mn48:2.1: This is in reference to the notorious quarrel at Kosambī, also referred to at MN 128:2.1. The events are detailed in the Vinaya at Kd 10.
comment_text.mn48:6.2: Also taught at MN 104:21.1, AN 6.11:1.1, and AN 6.12:1.1, and collected at DN 33:2.2.37 and DN 34:1.7.3.
comment_text.mn48:11.5: Vinaya offences fall into a number of classes, all of which must be confessed by a guilty monastic to their fellow monastics. Some are resolved upon confession, others by undergoing a procedure of relinquishment or temporary suspension. However, the most serious offences—sexual intercourse, murder, stealing, and lying about spiritual attainments—entail immediate and permanent expulsion. Offences are further distinguished by intention, as some offences may be transgressed without ill intent or even unknowingly (for example, eating at the wrong time). A stream-enterer cannot commit an expulsion offence, but they may commit one of the other offences without ill intent.
comment_text.mn48:12.6: The verb apacinati is an irregular form of apacāyati, to “watch” but also to “revere”.
comment_text.mn48:15.1: Normally sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya is dative, “for the realization of the fruit of stream-entry”, but that cannot be the case here as they are already a stream-enterer. The commentary reads it as instrumental.

root_text.mn48:1.2: ekaṁ samayaṁ bhagavā kosambiyaṁ viharati ghositārāme.
root_text.mn48:2.1: Tena kho pana samayena kosambiyaṁ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti.
root_text.mn48:2.2: Te na ceva aññamaññaṁ saññāpenti na ca saññattiṁ upenti, na ca aññamaññaṁ nijjhāpenti, na ca nijjhattiṁ upenti.
root_text.mn48:3.1: Atha kho aññataro bhikkhu yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdi. Ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so bhikkhu bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
root_text.mn48:3.2: “idha, bhante, kosambiyaṁ bhikkhū bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharanti, te na ceva aññamaññaṁ saññāpenti, na ca saññattiṁ upenti, na ca aññamaññaṁ nijjhāpenti, na ca nijjhattiṁ upentī”ti.
root_text.mn48:4.1: Atha kho bhagavā aññataraṁ bhikkhuṁ āmantesi:
root_text.mn48:4.2: “ehi tvaṁ, bhikkhu, mama vacanena te bhikkhū āmantehi:
root_text.mn48:4.4: “Evaṁ, bhante”ti kho so bhikkhu bhagavato paṭissutvā yena te bhikkhū tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā te bhikkhū etadavoca:
root_text.mn48:4.6: “Evamāvuso”ti kho te bhikkhū tassa bhikkhuno paṭissutvā yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkamiṁsu; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavantaṁ abhivādetvā ekamantaṁ nisīdiṁsu. Ekamantaṁ nisinne kho te bhikkhū bhagavā etadavoca:
root_text.mn48:4.7: “saccaṁ kira tumhe, bhikkhave, bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharatha,
root_text.mn48:4.8: te na ceva aññamaññaṁ saññāpetha, na ca saññattiṁ upetha, na ca aññamaññaṁ nijjhāpetha, na ca nijjhattiṁ upethā”ti?
root_text.mn48:5.2: yasmiṁ tumhe samaye bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharatha, api nu tumhākaṁ tasmiṁ samaye mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ …pe… mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho cā”ti?
root_text.mn48:5.4: “Iti kira, bhikkhave, yasmiṁ tumhe samaye bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharatha, neva tumhākaṁ tasmiṁ samaye mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca, na mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ …pe… na mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:5.5: Atha kiñcarahi tumhe, moghapurisā, kiṁ jānantā kiṁ passantā bhaṇḍanajātā kalahajātā vivādāpannā aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudantā viharatha, te na ceva aññamaññaṁ saññāpetha, na ca saññattiṁ upetha, na ca aññamaññaṁ nijjhāpetha, na ca nijjhattiṁ upetha?
root_text.mn48:5.6: Tañhi tumhākaṁ, moghapurisā, bhavissati dīgharattaṁ ahitāya dukkhāyā”ti.
root_text.mn48:6.2: “chayime, bhikkhave, dhammā sāraṇīyā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.mn48:6.4: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ kāyakammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:6.5: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.6: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ vacīkammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:6.7: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.8: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhuno mettaṁ manokammaṁ paccupaṭṭhitaṁ hoti sabrahmacārīsu āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:6.9: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.10: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu ye te lābhā dhammikā dhammaladdhā antamaso pattapariyāpannamattampi, tathārūpehi lābhehi appaṭivibhattabhogī hoti sīlavantehi sabrahmacārīhi sādhāraṇabhogī.
root_text.mn48:6.11: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.12: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāni tāni sīlāni akhaṇḍāni acchiddāni asabalāni akammāsāni bhujissāni viññuppasatthāni aparāmaṭṭhāni samādhisaṁvattanikāni tathārūpesu sīlesu sīlasāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:6.13: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.14: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, bhikkhu yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya tathārūpāya diṭṭhiyā diṭṭhisāmaññagato viharati sabrahmacārīhi āvi ceva raho ca.
root_text.mn48:6.15: Ayampi dhammo sāraṇīyo piyakaraṇo garukaraṇo saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattati.
root_text.mn48:6.16: Ime kho, bhikkhave, cha sāraṇīyā dhammā piyakaraṇā garukaraṇā saṅgahāya avivādāya sāmaggiyā ekībhāvāya saṁvattanti.
root_text.mn48:7.1: Imesaṁ kho, bhikkhave, channaṁ sāraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ etaṁ aggaṁ etaṁ saṅgāhikaṁ etaṁ saṅghāṭanikaṁ—yadidaṁ yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
root_text.mn48:7.2: Seyyathāpi, bhikkhave, kūṭāgārassa etaṁ aggaṁ etaṁ saṅgāhikaṁ etaṁ saṅghāṭanikaṁ yadidaṁ kūṭaṁ;
root_text.mn48:7.3: evameva kho, bhikkhave, imesaṁ channaṁ sāraṇīyānaṁ dhammānaṁ etaṁ aggaṁ etaṁ saṅgāhikaṁ etaṁ saṅghāṭanikaṁ yadidaṁ yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya.
root_text.mn48:8.1: Kathañca, bhikkhave, yāyaṁ diṭṭhi ariyā niyyānikā niyyāti takkarassa sammā dukkhakkhayāya?
root_text.mn48:8.2: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn48:8.3: ‘atthi nu kho me taṁ pariyuṭṭhānaṁ ajjhattaṁ appahīnaṁ, yenāhaṁ pariyuṭṭhānena pariyuṭṭhitacitto yathābhūtaṁ nappajāneyyaṁ na passeyyan’ti?
root_text.mn48:8.4: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu kāmarāgapariyuṭṭhito hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.5: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu byāpādapariyuṭṭhito hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.6: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu thinamiddhapariyuṭṭhito hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.7: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu uddhaccakukkuccapariyuṭṭhito hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.8: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu vicikicchāpariyuṭṭhito hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.9: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu idhalokacintāya pasuto hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.10: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu paralokacintāya pasuto hoti, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.
root_text.mn48:8.11: Sace, bhikkhave, bhikkhu bhaṇḍanajāto kalahajāto vivādāpanno aññamaññaṁ mukhasattīhi vitudanto viharati, pariyuṭṭhitacittova hoti.

root_text.mn48:8.15: Idamassa paṭhamaṁ ñāṇaṁ adhigataṁ hoti ariyaṁ lokuttaraṁ asādhāraṇaṁ puthujjanehi.

root_text.mn48:9.2: ‘imaṁ nu kho ahaṁ diṭṭhiṁ āsevanto bhāvento bahulīkaronto labhāmi paccattaṁ samathaṁ, labhāmi paccattaṁ nibbutin’ti?
root_text.mn48:9.4: ‘imaṁ kho ahaṁ diṭṭhiṁ āsevanto bhāvento bahulīkaronto labhāmi paccattaṁ samathaṁ, labhāmi paccattaṁ nibbutin’ti.
root_text.mn48:9.5: Idamassa dutiyaṁ ñāṇaṁ adhigataṁ hoti ariyaṁ lokuttaraṁ asādhāraṇaṁ puthujjanehi.

root_text.mn48:11.2: ‘yathārūpāya dhammatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato, ahampi tathārūpāya dhammatāya samannāgato’ti.

root_text.mn48:11.10: desetvā vivaritvā uttānīkatvā āyatiṁ saṁvaraṁ āpajjati.

root_text.mn48:11.13: Idamassa catutthaṁ ñāṇaṁ adhigataṁ hoti ariyaṁ lokuttaraṁ asādhāraṇaṁ puthujjanehi.

root_text.mn48:13.1: Puna caparaṁ, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako iti paṭisañcikkhati:
root_text.mn48:13.2: ‘yathārūpāya balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato, ahampi tathārūpāya balatāya samannāgato’ti.
root_text.mn48:13.3: Kathaṁrūpāya ca, bhikkhave, balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato?

root_text.mn48:13.6: ‘yathārūpāya balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato, ahampi tathārūpāya balatāya samannāgato’ti.
root_text.mn48:13.7: Idamassa chaṭṭhaṁ ñāṇaṁ adhigataṁ hoti ariyaṁ lokuttaraṁ asādhāraṇaṁ puthujjanehi.

root_text.mn48:14.2: ‘yathārūpāya balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato, ahampi tathārūpāya balatāya samannāgato’ti.
root_text.mn48:14.3: Kathaṁrūpāya ca, bhikkhave, balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato?

root_text.mn48:14.6: ‘yathārūpāya balatāya diṭṭhisampanno puggalo samannāgato, ahampi tathārūpāya balatāya samannāgato’ti.
root_text.mn48:14.7: Idamassa sattamaṁ ñāṇaṁ adhigataṁ hoti ariyaṁ lokuttaraṁ asādhāraṇaṁ puthujjanehi.
root_text.mn48:15.1: Evaṁ sattaṅgasamannāgatassa kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvakassa dhammatā susamanniṭṭhā hoti sotāpattiphalasacchikiriyāya.
root_text.mn48:15.2: Evaṁ sattaṅgasamannāgato kho, bhikkhave, ariyasāvako sotāpattiphalasamannāgato hotī”ti.
root_text.mn48:15.4: Attamanā te bhikkhū bhagavato bhāsitaṁ abhinandunti.

translation_text.mn48:1.2: At one time the Buddha was staying near Kosambī, in Ghosita’s Monastery.
translation_text.mn48:2.1: Now at that time the mendicants of Kosambī were fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words.
translation_text.mn48:2.2: They couldn’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor could they convince each other or be convinced.
translation_text.mn48:3.1: Then a mendicant went up to the Buddha, bowed, sat down to one side, and told him what was happening.
translation_text.mn48:4.1: So the Buddha addressed one of the monks,
translation_text.mn48:4.2: “Please, monk, in my name tell those mendicants that
translation_text.mn48:4.4: “Yes, sir,” that monk replied. He went to those monks and said,
translation_text.mn48:4.6: “Yes, reverend,” those monks replied. They went to the Buddha, bowed, and sat down to one side. The Buddha said to them,
translation_text.mn48:4.7: “Is it really true, mendicants, that you have been fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words?
translation_text.mn48:4.8: And that you can’t persuade each other or be persuaded, nor can you convince each other or be convinced?”
translation_text.mn48:5.2: When you’re fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding each other with barbed words, are you treating your spiritual companions with kindness by way of body, speech, and mind, both in public and in private?”
translation_text.mn48:5.4: “So it seems that when you’re arguing you are not treating each other with kindness.
translation_text.mn48:5.5: So what then do you know and see, you futile men, that you behave in such a way?
translation_text.mn48:5.6: This will be for your lasting harm and suffering.”
translation_text.mn48:6.1: Then the Buddha said to the mendicants:
translation_text.mn48:6.2: “Mendicants, these six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
translation_text.mn48:6.4: Firstly, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with bodily kindness, both in public and in private.
translation_text.mn48:6.5: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
translation_text.mn48:6.6: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with verbal kindness …
translation_text.mn48:6.8: Furthermore, a mendicant consistently treats their spiritual companions with mental kindness …
translation_text.mn48:6.10: Furthermore, a mendicant shares without reservation any material things they have gained by legitimate means, even the food placed in the alms-bowl, using them in common with their ethical spiritual companions …
translation_text.mn48:6.12: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the precepts shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. Those precepts are intact, impeccable, spotless, and unmarred, liberating, praised by sensible people, not mistaken, and leading to immersion. …
translation_text.mn48:6.14: Furthermore, a mendicant lives according to the view shared with their spiritual companions, both in public and in private. That view is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering.
translation_text.mn48:6.15: This warm-hearted quality makes for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
translation_text.mn48:6.16: These six warm-hearted qualities make for fondness and respect, conducing to inclusion, harmony, and unity, without quarreling.
translation_text.mn48:7.1: Of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
translation_text.mn48:7.2: It’s like a bungalow. The roof-peak is the chief point, which holds and binds everything together.
translation_text.mn48:7.3: In the same way, of these six warm-hearted qualities, the chief is the view that is noble and emancipating, and delivers one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering. It holds and binds everything together.
translation_text.mn48:8.1: And how does the view that is noble and emancipating lead one who practices it to the complete ending of suffering?
translation_text.mn48:8.2: It’s when a mendicant has gone to a wilderness, or to the root of a tree, or to an empty hut, and reflects like this,
translation_text.mn48:8.3: ‘Is there anything that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see?’
translation_text.mn48:8.4: If a mendicant is overcome with sensual desire, it’s their mind that’s overcome.
translation_text.mn48:8.5: If a mendicant is overcome with ill will,
translation_text.mn48:8.10: pursuing speculation about the next world,
translation_text.mn48:8.11: or fighting, quarreling, and disputing, continually wounding others with barbed words, it’s their mind that’s overcome.
translation_text.mn48:8.13: ‘There is nothing that I’m overcome with internally and haven’t given up, because of which I might not accurately know and see.
translation_text.mn48:8.14: My heart is properly disposed for awakening to the truths.’
translation_text.mn48:8.15: This is the first knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is distinct from that of ordinary people.
translation_text.mn48:9.2: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, do I personally gain serenity and quenching?’
translation_text.mn48:9.4: ‘When I develop, cultivate, and make much of this view, I personally gain serenity and quenching.’
translation_text.mn48:10.2: ‘Are there any ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have?’
translation_text.mn48:10.4: ‘There are no ascetics or brahmins outside of the Buddhist community who have the same kind of view that I have.’
translation_text.mn48:11.2: ‘Do I have the same nature as an individual accomplished in view?’
translation_text.mn48:11.3: And what, mendicants, is the nature of an individual accomplished in view?
translation_text.mn48:11.4: This is the nature of an individual accomplished in view.
translation_text.mn48:11.5: Though they may fall into a kind of offense for which rehabilitation is possible, they quickly disclose, clarify, and reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
translation_text.mn48:11.6: And having revealed it they restrain themselves in the future.
translation_text.mn48:11.7: Suppose there was a little baby boy. If he puts his hand or foot on a burning coal, he quickly pulls it back.
translation_text.mn48:11.8: In the same way, this is the nature of an individual accomplished in view.
translation_text.mn48:11.9: Though they may still fall into a kind of offense for which rehabilitation is possible, they quickly reveal it to the Teacher or a sensible spiritual companion.
translation_text.mn48:11.10: And having revealed it they restrain themselves in the future.
translation_text.mn48:11.12: ‘I have the same nature as an individual accomplished in view.’
translation_text.mn48:12.2: ‘Do I have the same nature as an individual accomplished in view?’
translation_text.mn48:12.3: And what, mendicants, is the nature of an individual accomplished in view?
translation_text.mn48:12.4: This is the nature of an individual accomplished in view.
translation_text.mn48:12.5: Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still feel a keen regard for the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.
translation_text.mn48:12.6: Suppose there was a cow with a baby calf. She watches her calf devotedly as she grazes.
translation_text.mn48:12.7: In the same way, this is the nature of an individual accomplished in view.
translation_text.mn48:12.8: Though they might manage a diverse spectrum of duties for their spiritual companions, they still feel a keen regard for the training in higher ethics, higher mind, and higher wisdom.
translation_text.mn48:12.10: ‘I have the same nature as an individual accomplished in view.’
translation_text.mn48:13.2: ‘Do I have the same strength as an individual accomplished in view?’
translation_text.mn48:13.3: And what, mendicants, is the strength of an individual accomplished in view?
translation_text.mn48:13.4: The strength of an individual accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they pay attention, apply the mind, concentrate wholeheartedly, and actively listen to the teaching.
translation_text.mn48:13.6: ‘I have the same strength as an individual accomplished in view.’
translation_text.mn48:14.2: ‘Do I have the same strength as an individual accomplished in view?’
translation_text.mn48:14.3: And what, mendicants, is the strength of an individual accomplished in view?
translation_text.mn48:14.4: The strength of an individual accomplished in view is that, when the teaching and training proclaimed by the Realized One are being taught, they find inspiration in the meaning and the teaching, and find joy connected with the teaching.
translation_text.mn48:14.6: ‘I have the same strength as an individual accomplished in view.’
translation_text.mn48:14.7: This is the seventh knowledge they have achieved that is noble and transcendent, and is distinct from that of ordinary people.
translation_text.mn48:15.1: When a noble disciple has these seven factors, they have properly investigated their nature through the realization of the fruit of stream-entry.
translation_text.mn48:15.2: A noble disciple with these seven factors has the fruit of stream-entry.”
translation_text.mn48:15.3: That is what the Buddha said.
translation_text.mn48:15.4: Satisfied, the mendicants approved what the Buddha said.
